bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Bureau of Highway Traffic, a nationally known center for post-graduate education in traffic engineering, was established at Harvard University in 1926. It devoted itself to purposes of training and to studies aimed toward furthering safe and efficient operations of streets, highways and parking terminals.

In 1938, the Bureau became part of Yale University, under the guidance of the Committee on Transportation, which was responsible for its operation. Upon successful completion of the one year course of graduate study, students were awarded a Certificate in Highway Transportation. The Bureau relocated from Yale to Pennsylvania State University in 1968.
